document.text: YELLOW VALLEY NEWS! O --------------------------------  O Yellow Valley, Feb. 20.- We have just received word of the marriage of Miss Jsssie Richardson and Eddie Cardwell, both of Lynchburg. They were married at Appomattox Satur day night, February 16. We wish them a life of happiness. A surprise- birthday party was given Leonard Carter in his home February 9. Quite a number were present and he received many nice gifts. The hostess served delightful refreshments. Miss Margie Joe Cawthorn, of Lyn chburg, spent the week-end with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. T. J. Caw thorn. Mrs. Ray Baldwin is recoovering from a spell of flu. Miss Josephine Hollycross, of Ap pomattox spent last week-end with her aunt.

document.text: without aid from the Govern ment. R. A . Cheatham was married on October 24, 1866 to Harriet Nelson CaWthorn, daughter of the Rev. John H. Cawthorn, a Baptist minister. They were the parents of eleven children, the youngest of whom Russell Aubrey Cheatham, served with tMfe Army in Europe during World War I. R . A . Cheatham died Nov. 6,1922 and is buried In the Cheatham Fanhily Cemetery three miles south west .of Appomattox, Va. on State Route 719. - I have always heard that my Grandfather was left on. the battlefield for dead, but an Appomattox soldier passing by found him and took him to the medical tent. They cleansed his chest wound by passing a silk hankerchief through it. His paralyzed left arm was cured by massaging over a period of years. My grandmothers fami ly did not want her to marry him as they did not think a man with only one arm could support her, a problem soldiers of ail wars have had to face.

document.text: William Pitzer Gills, who died at his home, Locust Grove, Friday morning, was the son of James Thomas and Cornelia Terri 1 Pitzer Gills. Though jiorn in Buckingham county, he moved to Appomattox in his boyhood on account of the death of his father. He then made his home with his uncle, the late Will iam Gills, who for many years was treasurer of the the county. He at tended the first public school evei taught in this county, Judge David A. Christian being the teacher. Mr. Gills engaged in various aeti- ties until the infirmities or age made, it necessary for him to retire from, public life. He was a senool trus.et of Appomattox county also serving as clerk to the school board, man carrier on R. F. D. No. 2, employed at one time by the Norfolk and Wes tern Railway, besides managing his arm near Appomattox. He was a iason and a Woodman of the  orld, and a Democr t who was un- werving in his par loyaly. Fii nany-lyears he was a faithful dea- on of Liberty Baptist church and teacher in the Sunday School. The deceased was a man whose lie was marked by fidelity to prin- ple. His was a goodly heritage of u ture and Godliness from an an cestry distinguished in the early history of America. Those who came in con4act with him were impressed by the deep spirituality of his nature. t  The funeral took place Sunday afternoon at Liberty Baptist church The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, the pastor, and the Rev. William May- field Thompson, a former pastor, conducting the services. The choir ,f the church sang Mr. Gills favor ite hymn, Rock of Ages. Tenny sons immortal poem, Crossing the Bar, was read and played on the pipe organ as a processional. Inter ment took place in the family plot in Liberty Cemetery, that part of the service. being conducted by the Masonic order. A host of friends and acquaintances, with many beautifa floral tributes attested to the love and high regard in which Mr. Gills was held in Appomattox and through out the state. Ihe active pallbearers were A. T. Inge, C. S. McDeormon, R. L. j Burk?, A. R. Harwood, J. C David son, N R. Featherston, B. G. An derson, Luther J. Morris. Honorary pallbearers included R. B. Hudgins, J. H. Lucado, T. W. Moses, Charles T. Moses, Pat Chand ler, L. Crawley, C. W. Smith, W. Stratton Taylor, Jennings Ferguson. T. Ed Owen, W. J. LeGrand, Dr. D. A. Christian, Dr. C. G OBrien, S L. Ferguson, Jr., J. H. OBrien, W. B. Caldyell, F. L. Murphy, E. VR-y Smith, Andrew Wingfield, H. C. Pul iam, Uoel Flood, Don Moses, John T. Cole, J. W. Caw son, John A. Iweedy, R. W. S an- ey, H. M. Burge, R. Travis Lee, F. A. OBrien, R. Edward OBrien, VV. W. OBrien, T. H. Inge, M. C. Imith, S. Guy Smith, R. C Wagner, J. A. Burke, Charlie Johnson, Pit zer Johnson, William Burke, D. A. Conner, D. E. Turnes, Jesse L. Tumes, James W. Caldwell, Harry Jenkins, Leonard Carter, E. Percy Sea, Odel! Howerton, Edmund H. Cawthorn, O. Cleveland Paulette. T. Morton Rosser, R. W. Smith, Leslie N. Ligon, L. E. Smith, C. N. Abbitt, J R Horsley, J. E. Chick, W. L. Brown, L. F. Ferguson, O P. Farrar, J. H. Cheatham, Dr. L L. Gayle, Dr. C. F. James, Robert Hubbard, Fitz Martin, Calvin H. Robinson, George F. Abbitt, Jr., T. W. Ferguson, Lester B. Harvey, J. D. Plunkett. Mr. Gills was first married to Miss Ella Pittman, who died some years ago. Two of the children of this union survive him, Henry Pitzer Gills of Marion, Virginia, and Mr 3 . Luth er B. Pittman, of Richmond. His second wife, who survives him, was Miss Albertha OBrien Of this mar riage, six children wire torn, James, passing away in inf.-ncy. The five living are Professor Allen Gils, of Clarksville Miss Cornelia Kyle Gills, of Appomattox Shelby Ken- nard Gills, of Richmond Mrs. Will iam Haller Copenhaver, of Marion Mrs. R. Banks Frazier, of Richmond. He also leaves five grandchildren, Mrs. R. S. Simpkins, of Chrisians- burg, Va. Mrs. Allen B. Pearcy, of Bristol, Penn. Joseph Pitzer Gills, of Pulaski, Va., Eloise Ogden, and Mary Joan Gills, of Clarksville, Va., and one brother, James T. Gills, of Lynchburg, his only other brother being the late Edmond Ernest Gills, of Appomattox.  And death itself, to him, was but The wider opening of the door Tha had been opening, more and more, Through all his life, and nevei as stiut. . . .

document.text: Whats new with you? Things at A. H. S. are happening right along, day by day. As the SCA is an important part of our school, we are always glad to hear of their activities. Last Mon- day they held a meeting during lunch period. At this meeting re ports from various committees such as safety, health, program, clean up and social were given. Thè stu dent council has decided to meet every Monday at lunch time. The SCA is working hard this year to help the school and students, so let us try to help them and ourselves. The Home Economics Club initia ted new members last week and they did a very good job. If you saw a girl wearing her mothers dess, high heels witth miss-matched socks, 30 clothespins in her hair and car rying a broom, she was a F. H. A. . We are proud of our football boys for defeating Amherst Friday night, 51 to 0. Ed Cawthorn wept over for five of our touchdowns, I whili Bobby Cfeemault, Henry Doss and Billy JohnsU it each scored one. This was our lan home gams ilvs year, bui dont forget we still have a game with VES Saturday a.id a I game - Farmville November 22, so be there and suoport your team.

document.text: Well the great campaign is over, next comes Thanksgiving Day, so lets give thanks to God for his protection and guidance. Mrs. Lillie Inge, who has just undergone a very serious opera tion at Baptist Hospital is get ting along as well as could be expected. Her daughter, Mrs. Lawrence Young, who was a re cent patient there, has returned home and is improving fast. We hope mother and daughter will soon be restored to health. Mr. James Alfred, of Bristo who has been visiting his grand daughter, Mrs. W. J. Smith, has returned to his home. Mrs. H. Smith and child ren, of Buckingham, were the guests ofMr8. J. J. Farrar Sat urday night. .... Rev. J. E. White and wife and Mr. and Mrs. J- P. Paulett at tended the district Stewards meeting in Lynchburg Saturday. Our community was shocked and saddened last Friday after noon by the sudden death of Mrs. Bettie Cawthorn. She was sit ting in her chair when the call came and she passed to her eternal4 home as a little child drops to sleep without a murmer.  She was a devoted mother, a kind friend and neighbor and will be missed in her church and community. She enjoyed ming ling with her friends and neigh bors. She is survived by the following children Edmond, Hector and Russell, Mesdames. J. R. Hamilton, S. J. Jennings, W S. Farrar and Sam Staples. She was laid to rest in the family cemetery at noon Sunday. Fun eral services were conducted by her pastor, Rev. J. E- Goad, as sisted by Rev- Lofflin of Church  Roads. Her popularity was attested by the unusual large crowd and beautiful floral, de signs. The family have deepest sympathy.

document.text: We w ere sad d led when word came Sunday that Mr. W. M. Blade had passed away. Our love and deepest sympathy are extended her loved ones. Our prayers and sympathy are with the family and loved ones of Mr. Zack Cheatham, who passed away last week. We were very sorry to learn of the illness of Mrs. Sandy Baldwin of North Dakota. Our sincere prayers are with her and each of the family. We were very sorry to hear of the death of Mrs. Alfred LeGrande. Deepest sympathy is extended her loved ones. Mr. James Maxwell returned home Friday from the hospital. We wish for him a very speedy recovery. The families of the late Mi. and M rs. W. L. Turnes celebrated their family reunion Sunday at the home of Mrs. J. L. Torrence. Mr. H. W. Jenkins and son, Mr. Robert Jenkins attended the funeral of Mrs. Ossie Key of Bedford Saturday. She was a very dear relative of the late Mrs. H. W. Jenkins. Mr. and Mrs. Bill Watson and family returned home Friday after spending their vacation at W illiamsburg and Virginia Beach. Visiting Mr. and Mrs. Robert Coleman last week were Mr. and Mrs. Calvin Smith, Bobby and Tammie Smith. Visiting MrJ and Mrs. Scott Sheets several days last week was his sister, Mrs. Violet Pittsinger of Eaton, Ohio and Mr. and Mrs. Paul Sheldon of Columbus, Ohio, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Greer and family are visiting in the home of Mr. and Mrs. L. L. Webb and family. Visiting Mr. and Mrs. L. H. Watson Sunday were Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Franklin, Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Wingfield, Miss Julia Wingfield and Mr. and Mrs. Eddie Wooten and son. Among others visiting in this home last week were Mr. and Mrs. Berkley Drinkard and family, Mr. and Mrs. Berkley Brown, Mr. and Mrs. Walker Shupe, Mr. Alfred Almond and Mr. and Mrs. Alton Lucado and family. Mrs. B. B. Harris, Sr. was a visitor Monday night of Mrs. Virgie Beasley, Mrs. Claude Hamlett and daughter Brenda spent Friday with M rs. Beasley. Mr. and Mrs. George Inge of Chester, VA visited her Saturday and Mr. Grover Beasley, Jr. visited her Sunday. Mrs. Holly Cawthom, Mrs. Rachel Cawthorn and Mrs. Raymond Harris were visitors in the homes of Mr. H. W. Jenkins, Mr. and Mrs. L. H. Watson and Mrs. Mary Bagby, Wednesday evening. Mr. and Mrs. A. B. Franklin, Jr. and family of Chase City were visitors Thursday after noon of Mr. and Mrs. R. M. Webb and family. Mrs. Elmo Smith recently spent a week with her sons at Grottos, VA. Mr. Smith spent the week end in this home. Mr. and M rs. Ryland M ayberry and M rs. loan Mayberry of Newport News spent the week end in the homes of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Deaner and family and Mr. and Mrs. Roy St.John. The W. H. Wingfields visited in the homes of Dr. and Mrs. Tom Sumaker and family and Mr. and M rs. Billy Inge Wednesday night. Dinner guest Thursday of Mrs. Mary Bagby were Mrs. Mary Higgins, Mrs. Shirley Carson, Mrs. Loveline Scruggs, Mrs. Katherine Wingfield, Mrs Ruby Woodall and daughter Tj. Calling in this home last week w ere M rs. M. L. Covington, Mrs. Andy Davis, Mrs. loan Mayberry, Mrs. Kenneth Deaner. Miss Dawn Deaner, Mr. H. W. Jenkins, Mrs. Shirley Franklin and daughter. Pamela. Mr. and Mrs. Frank Scham- pel were visitors Sunday night of M. and M rs. W. H. Wingfield and family. Mr. and Mr- K enneth Deaner and family. Mrs. loan Mayberry and Mr. And Mrs. Ryland Mayberry spent Sun day in Roanoke with Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Wingfield and family. They celebrated Mr. Wingfields birthday Sunday with a lovely dinner. document.text: We, the undersigned have seen a card in the New-Herald of Oct. 26, 1899, reflecting upon the mem bers of the Democratic Committee of Appomattox county, to which our names are signed. We desiri to state hat we never saw until to dav the address issued and pub lished by said Committee and after reading it are unable to point out hii incorrect sentence in it. We further state that we know every member of said Committee to be hightone. truthful gentlemen and would not and could not say or pub lish one word detrimental to the eleven gentlemen who compose the committee. We have never signed or authorized our names to be signed to the card above alluded to know ing its contents. E. N. Wooldridge, J. W. Evans, L. E. Rutledge, J. D. Cawthorn.

The Sunday School rooms of the Methodist Church is go ing up in a hurry. Mrs. Sallie Cawthorn, of Richmond, is the guest of her sister, Mrs. J. R. Lee, though confined to her wheel chair she is a comfort to her invalid sis ter. We delighted to see the progress that has been made at this church. May our God ever hold her up in the future as in he past. Rev William Warren preach ed at Rocks Church Sunday night. document.text: We are very proud of the foot ball team for their victory over Randolph-Henry of Charlotte Court House here last Friday nizii.. The score was 277. The touchdowns were made by Cawthorn, Doss and Mitchell. Chernault and Dos3 con verted for the extra points. We were sorry many of our playets suffeied injuries, but all of them are expect ed to see action in Fiiday nignts game at Blackstone. We notice 1 several members of last years foot ball squad at the game last Friday, namely Harry Gordon Lawson and Dick Marks, who are attending the University of Virginia.  Everyone is busy making- plans for the big Homecoming Day which is only one week from tomorrow. We would like to congratulate Jim my Harris and Martha Nash from the high school and Hal Flood and Robbie Lee Robertson of the grades, who were chosen to reign over this celebration. We appreciate the visit of Mr. William E. Hanson, Lynchburg, to our school on Monday and gave a talk to the members of Hi-Y and Tri-Y. He explained the aims - of these clubs. We hope he will visit us again. We were glad too hear that the photographer is coming next week to take pictures for the annual. Thats about all for this, week so, until we meet again somewhere be tween this week-end and next week or, if we dont, Ill see you next Thursday.

document.text: We are very proud and lappy to have six of our young eople of Hollywood Church graduating this year Lelia Maxwell, Debra Scruggs. De- orious Deaner, Beverley Cole- nan, Steve Cawthorn and Ben Maxwell. Congratulations to jach of them and all those graduating in the Class Í976 from Appomattox High. Bible School begins at Hollywood Church Monday, Tune 14, and will close Friday, June 18. The school will open at 9 a.m. and close at 12 noon each day. All the families and friends are invited to come Friday night at 8 oclock for the closing exercises.  Miss Julia Wingfield and the Acteens from Hollywood Chur ch called in the home of Mrs. Berkley Brown Sunday after Sunday School. The Acteens of Hollywood met in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Franklin and family Tuesday night for their June meeting. Mrs. i Paul Balthaser was a welcome-guest at themeeting. Mrs. Franklin served delightful refreshments and everyone enjoyed the social hour very much. Rev. Paul Balthaser went with Mr. H. W. Jenkins to visit Mr. Jenkink mother and sister at the Liberty House Nursing Home in Lynchburg Thursday. We are very sorry to hear Mr. Bennett Gilliam is á patient in the Lynchburg General Hospital. Relatives and friends are praying he may have a speedy recovery. Mr. and Mrs, W. H. Wingfield visited Mrs. Frank Woodall in the Lynchburg Hospital Friday night. We are so glad she is improving nicely. It was good to see Dawn Deaner at church Sunday. She was sick all last week with a virus. Mr. and Mrs. Martin Webb, Mrs. Thelma Martin and Mr. and Mrs. R. M. document.text: Water melons are plentiful. Mr. James Cawthorn carried a big load to Evergreen Saturday. Mrs. Daisy Woolridge attended  the funeral of Mr. John Lucado of Lynchburg on Friday last. Mr. John Bagby aud wife re turned home from Lynchburg last Saturday. Messrs. S. V. Beasley and M. L. Covington, attended the Appomat tox Association at Midway church in Charlotte las week. They report having nada glorious time. We need a phone line from here to Appomattox, and hope the people will soon become interested and put the line into operation. Mr. Taylor, the R. F. D. Inspec tor was with Mr. Alex WingfieW last Friday inspecting his route. Each correspondent of this paper should accord a vote of thanks to the author of that poetical jein in the last number of this paper, Aud I Will Give You Rest. Ah, yes we have read in the Book of truth where He said Come Ye that are heavy laden and I will give you rest. Mr. Jim Coghill has returned  to Roanoke after a weeks visit here.

document.text: violin, but no games or dancing was engaged All present said they had a good time. On the 25th all of the young people mostly went to the home of Mr. Sam Ransom where they had an enjoyable time and proBOunced Mis Gertie a charming hoses. On the 26th all to the home of Mr. J. L. Davis where they had one more good time, On the 27tb a good crowd assembl ed in the parlor at Mr. W. E. Wool ridge where they sang hymns and Miss Willie skillfully performed on the organ. On the 28th there was a big dance at the Hall. Music was rendered by our string b nd, Messrs. Ragland and Staples. On the 29th there was a large crowd paid Mr. Hutson Oheatham a call, and he did not fail to entertain them all O. K. Onr prayer meeting was conduct ed on the 30th by Dr. Wm. Abbitt. He gave a long interesting talk that was listened to with good attention, and we believe that it done much good. Rev. H. W. Dunkley will preach for us at Evergreen Church, on the 5th Sunday evening at 3 oclock. Gome one and all prepared to hear a good sermon. Your correspondent was present at Westley Chapel on Sunday last, and heard the best sermon that was ever preached on a Christians duty. If any church member that heard that sermon can ever dance again I dont know what to think. There was no prayer meeting on Wednesday night, and it was a fine sugar stew at Mr. Cheathams that he gave the boys for their kindness in helping him fill his ice-hou.e with ice 5 inches thick. Prayer meeting has m t been given out for next Wednesday night Air. E. H. Cawthorn wears a broad mile over the arrival of a flue boy at his house on the Cd inst, We_ wish him much happiness over hisjV  treasure and hope that he will raiael

document.text: Veteran Charles Henry Cole man, from Wreck Island was in town today looking none the worse after 87 summers. Mrs. J. H. Kidd and Mrs. C. W. Potts, of Lynchburg, spent Monday inthe home of A. H. Clement. , Miss Mildred Powell, of Lynchburg, is visiting, in the lome of Mr. and Mrs. M. H. Marks this week. Miss Lucille fsucado has re- urned from Richmond, where he has been visiting Miss Lu cille Morriss. Mr. Garland Torrence and 3isters, of Verlena, and Louise, of Hopewell, have been on a visit to home people here. Mr. and Mrs. J. R. Thomas, of Lynchburg, were Sunday guests of Mr. and Mrs. S. E. Torrence here.1 Mrs. ,A. E Torrence, who las been on! the slpk list is improving, also Mrs. J. L. Tor rence. Mrs. C. E. Torrence and daughter, Cecile, of Roanoke, lave been on a visit to home 1olks here. Mr. and Mrs. W. D. Griggs and children, of Hopewell, were guests of the latters brother, Mr. S. J. Evans last week. Mr. and Mrs. M. H. Marks and family attended ?the fam ily re-union given at the home of Mr. and Mrs. J. T. Trent Sunday. Mrs. E. H. Cawthorn, who las been visiting relatives at Appomattox and Pamplin for two weeks, returned to her lome in Roanoke on Sunday. Mr. and Mrs. Elwood Alvis and Miss Edith OBrien, of lichmond, were guests in the lome of F. A. OBrien for the holidays. Miss Nannie Harvey and Mr. Lenwood Harvey, of Bucking ham, were guests bf Misses Is abelle and Phoebe OBrien during last week-end. Miss Kathleen Wood and Mr. Claude Wood, of Lynch burg, were guests in the home of Mr. Pitzer Gills last week end. Mr. and Mrs. Meredith Mc Faden, of Buckingham, spent last week with their sister, Mrs. Andrew Carter, near here. I.iitie Royal Hancock, J r. of Raleigh, N. C., has returned home after visiting his grand parents, Mr. and Mrs L. M. Drinkard for several weeks. A very highly bred guernsey bull calf has been awarded to Master Jas. Langran, of this place by Mr. Warren S. Corn ing. Mrs. Louella Morris and daughter, Mrs. Helen Welch, have returned to their home after an extended stay in Lynchburg. The regular monthly meet ing of the U. D. C. will take place at the residence of Mrs. W. L. Brown at 330 Thurs day, Jjuly the 17th. Dr. Price and family, of Clarksville, Va., were visitors at the home of Warren S. Corn ing this week. The doctor is one of the big live stock growers of Va.

document.text: Very hotand exceedingly dry. I We had a nice shower last I week but need, more badly Some thermometers registered 104 Sunday afternoon, in J shade. Elkton Hamilton, of Chic-1 ago, has been here visiting I his parents, Mr. and Mrs. B. H. Hamilton. . Mias Louise Stratten is visit ing her aunt, Mrs.J. H. Elder, in Richmond. Mrs. C. N. Price, of Lynchburg, is also  her guest. Mrs. Elder and! family and guests are camping this week at Boilers Wharf. I Mrs. Alice Jacobs a n d daughters, Bettie and Dot, of Richmond, are guests of th e 1 formers parents for several weeks, Mr. and Mrs. C. M. Stratten, Sr. Mr. Jacobs and children are spending several days with I Mrs. Jacobs sister, Mrs. D. A. Christian at Appomattox. Mr. Jacobs is touring Europe for several months. Misses Hazel Taylor and Ethel Alvis and John Taylor motored to Richmond Satur day. John returned Sunday, the girls remained for a longer visit. Mr. and Mrs. Allen Chick, Mrs. Aubrey Thomas and little daughter Ann, were Sunday guests of Mr. J. A. Stratten and family. Mr. and Mrs. Cal Chick, of Norfolk, are visiting relatives in the county this week. Mrs. Mary Carson Cawthorn of Newark, N. J., has conclud ed a two weeks visit with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. C. E. Carson. Mrs. E. H. Carson is visiting her son, Owen Carson for a few days.. Miss Landis Laughan and mother, Kermit, have recent ly visited relatives in Rich mond. Mrs. J. W. Neighbors, Jr., and children were guests of Ir. and Mrs. Neighbors a few days last week. Mr. and Mrs. S. E. Ander son spent Sunday afternoon with Mr. and Mrs. Tom Tay lor near Beckham. Mr. and Mrs. Dunkley Gun- er, and son, Bobbie, Mr. and Mrs. Sam Stratten and Mr. and drs. Asby Anderson, of Lynch burg, motored to Crewe and Crystal Lake Sunday. Mrs. Seay, of Lynchburg, spent he week-end with Mrs. S. E. Anderson. Supervisor S- E. Anderson ias purchased a new Ford from Rustburg.
